data.title: Court orders removal of Sivaji statue
data.meta_description: Court orders removal of Sivaji statue
data.text:
The Chennai High Court has ordered the removal of a statue of late film actor Sivaji Ganesan at a busy traffic junction on Marina Beach road.

A petition was filed in the court saying the statue was hindering traffic.

However Sivaji’s fan club members have obtained a stay.

In another case, a court in Salem overruled the objections against the installation of a statue of late DMK minister Veerapandi Arumugham at Omalur main road. A local group invoked a court order stating that the statue was on government usurped property.

However the court allowed the inauguration of the statue by M K Stalin, the deputy chief of the party on January 25.

Chennai kidney racket busted, six arrested

Six people including two women who had planned to ‘sell’ their kidneys were arrested at Kilpauk hospital in Chennai last week.

The gang included three female brokers and the husband of one of the ‘donors’.

Police said the brokers Girija, Sophia and Devi were running a racket luring poor women to sell their kidneys and collecting commission. They had also forged documents to show the donors as related to the recipients.

Police said the brokers had sold their own kidneys.

This violated the Transplantation of Human Organs Act 1994 that decreed that only relatives and close friends could receive donor kidneys.

Veteran actor in hospital

Yesteryear Tamil actor S S Rajendran, who is a contemporary of late actors Sivaji Ganesan and M G Ramachandran, was hospitalised for chest congestion in Chennai last week.

The 88-year-old Rajendran has acted in over 300 Tamil films after debuting in 1952 in Parasakthi with Sivaji Ganesan. He is an avid theatre artiste and has produced many films, dramas and television soaps in a six-decade career. He is also the founder member of the South Indian Artistes Association and had a short stint in politics.

He has three wives including actress Vijayakumari and many children.

Convict in Rajiv case seeks parole

Nalini Sriharan, sentenced to life in late prime minister Rajeev Gandhi’s assassination case, has applied to the Madras High Court for parole as she says she has to look after her father, a retired police inspector, at Ambalavanapuram village in Tirunelveli district.

If granted it will be Nalini’s second parole in her 22- year incarceration. Nalini said her 90-year-old father was ailing and that she had not met him for eight years.

Nalini had a daughter with fellow convict Murugan during her jail term who now being looked after by her relatives.

Govt takes to cloud computing

Chief Minister Jayaram Jayalalithaa granted Rs110mn for installing cloud computing facility at the State Data Centre of the Tamil Nadu government last week.

The chief minister said this would help the State Data Centre provide quick and secure sharing of Net-related documents among all departments under its jurisdiction. Cloud computing would also cut costs of hiring infrastructure for each department.

The State Data Centre is a collaborative effort between the federal and state governments for e-governance initiatives.

Three killed by speeding van

A speeding van knocked down five women killing three of them instantly and injuring the others at Attayampatti on Ariyanur state highway in suburban Salem last week.
